The District welcomed the staff back in a unique and fun team-building way for their first day back of the 2020-21 school year with a surprise --the staff got to participate in ASD's First Annual--"The Amazing Race - Pagosa style".

The teams raced to complete a series of 12 tasks from clues that took them all over town racing to do such things as: take a picture with the county commissioner, find the Safety Resource Officers in your school and take a selfie with them, document Family School Bee House messages, sing the Pagosa Pirates fight song on stage...and so much more. Teams raced to the finish line at the stadium where they joined their peers for some water and a snack.

What a fun way to start the year off together as staff. We love our staff and we cant wait to see our students again soon. Go Pirates!!! 2020-21 is going to be a year to remember!!!

Davis flies his drone for the students and takes their annual graduation year photo. Each May, the 4th grade class spells out their future graduation year and Davis is able to snap a picture from above. Very cool!

The younger students now have goals to be drone pilots and the elementary school continues its tradition of celebrating the out-going 4th grade class with a special photo.

We are ASD proud!! #carereignshere

Next week is Thanksgiving, and always at this time of the year, I, like many others, look for things in my life that I am grateful for. When Assistant Superintendent Laura Mijares sent me this link, I knew I had found it ‚Äî the thing I'm most grateful for this year.

It's a story, but much more than just a story. This story is inspiring, uplifting, and real. It's a story about a family overcoming adversity and lack, yet through those hardships, this family was able to instill hope and a true sense of giving back in their children.

You probably know this family. And that is the real reason I'm grateful today. Each and every one of us could tell a story of struggle and pain, and when I hear or read a story about someone I know who rises above difficulties, I am so grateful for their gift to the rest of us.

So whatever you're facing this holiday season, take heart. There are many amongst us who know what you're going through and have come out the other end with their human spirit intact. That is where our future lies.

Michele Ziegler is volunteering at the elementary school and needs help watching and guiding the little bike riders. There are two groups of riders ‚Äî one group that is brand new to riding and will be on glide bikes and will need most all of Michele's attention. The other group is bikers who are riding without training wheels and will just have a simple course to ride, working on stopping, turning, and signaling. The hope is to do a couple riding sessions in the next few weeks that will be about 30 mins each, two classes so about an hour on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday afternoons. Dates will depend on volunteer availability. The first class will be from 1:45-2:15 and then 2:15-2:45. It will take about three weeks to get through all first graders this fall, and then in the spring we do a few hour-long sessions on the bikes. Those dates and times are yet to be decided.

Contact Doug Hershey, Proud Partners Program Coordinator, at dhershey@pagosa.k12.co.us

In his recent trip to Guatemala, Vice President Mike Pence and his wife, Karen, visited the U.S. Army base, where they visited troops and took time for a photo shoot on June 28, 2018. Standing next to Mrs. Pence is Staff Sergeant Raul Palmer, a graduate of Pagosa Springs High School.

A former football and wrestling athlete, Raul was honored to stand close to the VP and his wife. He has served in the military since graduating from high school in 2005. Palmer and others in his troop received a commemorative coin from Second Lady Karen Pence.

"You never know where life is going to take you," says his father, Butch Palmer, who passed on the photo. ASD recognizes and salutes Raul for his many years serving his country.
